text:
BRIDGET EVERETT (ACTOR/COMEDIAN): I just want 
to walk around with you all the time because

I feel like you take what I’m trying to 
say, you pull it right into focus, and

um, so just, just cut to me every once 
in a while, and we’ll bounce back to you.

BRITTANY LUSE (HOST): You’re watching It’s 
Been a Minute from NPR. I’m Brittany Luse.

My guest today is actor, producer, and cabaret 
singer Bridget Everett. She’s one of the stars

and creators of a show I absolutely 
adore: “Somebody Somewhere” on HBO.

The show centers on Bridget’s character, Sam, 
a spirited, but withdrawn forty-something who

recently returned to her hometown of Manhattan, 
Kansas. That’s where Bridget’s from, too.

The series opens as Sam tries to come to 
terms with the recent death of her older

sister, and follows as she embarks on new 
friendships, and mends old family bonds.

(SOUNDBITE OF TV SHOW, "SOMEBODY SOMEWHERE")
EVERETT: (As Sam) Joel, this is for you.

It’s a perfect comfort watch – it’s 
quiet, sweet, and laugh-out-loud funny.

(SOUNDBITE OF TV SHOW, "SOMEBODY SOMEWHERE")
EVERETT: (As Sam, singing) One tini tini and

another tini tini (laughing).
LUSE:

Bridget Everett, welcome to IT'S BEEN A MINUTE.
EVERETT: Thank you. Thanks for having me.

LUSE: Oh, my gosh. My absolute pleasure.
EVERETT: So cool. I walked in the NPR

building. I feel - you know, I feel pretty good.
LUSE: (Laughter) I'm glad that we've kept it

very legit for you today.
EVERETT: Yeah (laughter).

LUSE: Okay, Bridget, to start off. I know 
that you studied music and Opera. I also

was a child Opera singer. I used to sing 
children’s parts in operas when I was a kid.

EVERETT: Nice. Nice.
LUSE: I’m wondering,

what are some of your favorite vocal warmups?
EVERETT: I do this…I studied with Liz Caplan

for a while and she would do 
this thing (vocal exercises).

But the thing that I really like to 
do the most is, like, (snorting).

LUSE: What?
EVERETT: Because it loosens your,

like, situation back there.
LUSE: What you just did the

snort. That's the warmup.
EVERETT: Yeah. That's one

of the things that you do to sort of, 
like, keep it - to sort of (snorting).

LUSE: (Laughter). That’s something I just do 
involuntarily when I laugh a lot. But I didn’t

realize that that’s a warm-up.
EVERETT: It’s good for you.

LUSE: It’s legit.
EVERETT: Yeah, it’s legit. Keep it.

LUSE: I’m going to keep it. Thank you. 
You’ve given me something I can take

home today (laughing). Okay also, 
on your show, your character Sam,

on "Somebody Somewhere," your character, Sam, 
she frequently makes up, like, little ditties.

EVERETT: Yeah.
LUSE: What's your favorite of them

that we could share (laughter) on NPR?
EVERETT:

One of them is something that I used to sing 
with my friend, like, back in the '90s because

I would always forget my keys. It was like, 
(singing) keys, phone, cash, ID. Keys, phone...

LUSE: Yes.
EVERETT:

And then you had…you know just dumb things like 
that, but, that's something that I'd do every

day. I like to sort of sing to myself and sing to 
the people around me, just dumb, little things.

LUSE: Well, I mean, it works.
EVERETT: I guess I'm on HBO now,

so maybe it's - maybe it was smart. (Laughter).
LUSE: Maybe it was smart. Maybe it was smart. So

on that note, HBO - you got this amazing 
show, "Somebody Somewhere." It's coming

back for its second season. For people who 
haven’t seen "Somebody Somewhere," like,

explain what the show is and what it’s about.
EVERETT: Ultimately, it’s about not giving up

on yourself. And it’s about friendship, kind 
pf meeting somebody later in life and learning

how to fall in love with them, as a friend. You 
know? And, there’s not like a huge premise. You,

know there’s not like a lot of story and 
plot. It’s just more about sitting in a

room with people and kind of, living with 
them as they’re going through something.

LUSE: Mhm. I mean on the show, your 
character, Sam, moves back to Manhattan,

Kansas. Not as bustling as Manhattan, New York.
EVERETT: It’s literally called “The Little Apple.”

LUSE: “The Little Apple.” Exactly. One of the 
things that we've been talking about on our

team as we're preparing to talk to you, in one of 
the meetings that we were in, I realized that I

was the only, as I said, country mouse. Everybody 
else is from a city. I really have enjoyed, like,

sort of the pace of the show. I think that 
you captured how it feels really accurately.

EVERETT: Well that, that makes me happy to 
hear because, you know, Paul and Hannah,

who are our show creators, they’re Midwestern, 
and I’m from Kansas, obviously. And,

I don’t know, we just didn't want to do 
anything, like, snarky. We want to do something

kind, I guess. I know that word gets like, you 
know, jockeyed around a lot. But, um, I just feel

like we wanted to do something kind of simple.
LUSE: Hmm.

EVERETT: And hope that it 
wasn’t too simple (laughing).

LUSE: No, no, no.
EVERETT: But we like watching it and we’re like,

if we like it then hopefully somebody else will.
LUSE: I would love to know from you what is the

thing that you love most about Manhattan, Kansas?
EVERETT: You know, what I love most is the thing

that I, that I ran from, is, like, community. 
You know, when we were doing the show,

and we sort of needed boots on the ground for 
something, I could call like my brother – my

oldest brother - or my best friend, Stephanie, 
who lives there and like, there’s something

about that. Like, I found my community in New 
York, obviously. But, I don't know. There was,

like - the small town-ness of it I couldn't get 
away from fast enough. But now I sort of need it.

LUSE: Hm.
EVERETT: You know, I, I miss it.

LUSE: Executive producer Carolyn Strauss called 
"Somebody Somewhere" a coming of middle-age story,

which I thought was so interesting. I feel 
like so many narratives in TV and film are

concerned with, like, hitting specific 
markers of adulthood, like parenting,

you know, having kids, purchasing a home, like, 
climbing up the career ladder. And Sam's not

really concerned about any of those things. Some 
of those things she doesn’t even necessarily want,

even in some ways, sometimes as the viewer, I’m 
not even sure that Sam herself, fully knows what

she wants out of life, still in a period where 
I think culturally and like, pop culturally,

you’re expected to have everything kind of figured 
out. To me, Sam seems like she's in the process of

defining herself for herself. Outside of any of 
those things, I wonder, is there, like, a point

of self-definition that you hope that Sam gets to?
EVERETT: Wow, these are such really thoughtful

questions. I think that for Sam and I think for 
a lot of people, like, not everything has to be

marriage, kids, career - all that. I think Sam 
is more inch-by-inch. It is fun to think about

where she’s going and how she’s going to get 
there because it doesn’t seem like she really

has anything specific in mind. But, I'm kind of 
like that, too. Like, I always think about what's

right in front of me. I don't think about, like, 
I want to do this in my career. I want to have

this kind of personal life. I just sort of take it 
day-by-day, and I think that that's something you

don't really see on TV because it could be kind 
of boring because there's not a lot going on,

but we really try to show Sam's internal life 
and her growth, as slow as it is, and meeting

somebody like Joel, who's, like, so full of 
life and full of direction and full of purpose.

LUSE: And Joel is her best friend...
EVERETT: And Joel's her

best friend - yeah, exactly.
LUSE: ...Who she's kind of reunited with.

EVERETT: Yeah.
LUSE: Like a high school friend, she reunites

with him. They just stick to each other.
EVERETT: Yeah, and I think the thing - you know,

she'd probably still be on her own 
if he wasn't so undeniable. He's so

warm and sweet and he just has a gentleness about 
him that um, that feels warm and safe for her. And

what I love about the story is about how 
somebody like that can sort of slowly

bring you back to life, and it is a slow burn. 
It is a slow crawl. You know, I have friends that

have been putting in a lot of work with me for a 
lot of years, and um, I think that that’s just a,

it’s a different kind of story, and I guess 
that's kind of what we're trying to do.

LUSE: No, I mean...I noticed that when you talk 
about Sam - you kind of almost talk about Sam

and yourself, not completely interchangeably, but 
sort of noticing that there are some similarities

between you as a person and also who Sam is, like, 
at her core as a character. I mean, you know,

you've said in interviews before that Sam is kind 
of like who you would be if maybe you had never

left Manhattan, Kansas, where you're actually 
from, or if you had never come to New York,

um, and that the show is, in 
some ways, semi-autobiographical.

Has the show allowed you to reflect on yourself 
or moments from your life in a different way?

EVERETT: Yeah, absolutely. What I love about 
Sam is that – and I call her Sam because like,

if we’re in the editing room, I don’t want to be 
like, “Well you just did that. Bridget just did

that.” It’s Sam. She’s a character.
LUSE: Right.

EVERETT: And she takes bigger emotional swings 
that I would, even though they're small. Like...

LUSE: Yeah.
EVERETT: ...I just think that,

um, I think there's a lot I can learn from her 
and a lot that - of me that's infused in her. But,

the way that her friends, especially Joel, and 
her sister this, in this season, sort of, either

gently or abruptly, help her sort of see herself 
and, and help lift her up and dig her out of where

she is. I, I think Sam is as willing to face that, 
where I would just be like, “You know what? I’ve

got to go.” And I'd, and I'd hit the road. Go, 
go lay on the couch and snuggle up with my dog.

And be like, “well you still, love me, right?”
LUSE: It's almost like an emotional practice,

or something (laughing).
EVERETT: Yeah. And specifically with my

own family, you know, we have a sister who passed 
away, and so what's great about doing this show,

for me, is I never really dealt with my grief, 
and my family and I - we don't talk about it. If

we do anything, you know, we're very Midwestern. 
At least our family has a way of deflection. You

know, we sort of, like, deflect a lot with humor 
and don't really talk about her. So the show has

been a way to kind of think about my own grief 
and think about the way grief sort of infects

your life - how it, how it - at first, it's 
so overwhelming, but then how it just sort of,

you know, it, it comes in waves and it just 
pops up one day and totally takes your breath

away. And so in season two, when Sam is dealing 
with her sister and - you know, my own sister

and I - we don't have the kind of relationship 
where we're having these, like, conversations

about how we really feel, you know? We just 
don't do that. And Sam and Tricia, her sister,

really get at it because Tricia is making Sam talk 
about things. She's pushing her, but Sam also kind

of can't help herself. And, like, I feel that way 
sometimes. And, like, I want to be able to talk

about this, and we just don't do it, and Sam does 
in, like - in the way that your family can kind of

lay you bare or sort of strip you to the, 
you know - just hit your nerve in, like,

one second and how it can completely unravel 
you. And that's why I love the season two arc

with Tricia, her sister, because I feel like, 
it’s just, Tricia is growing, and Sam is just

stuck. I don't know.
LUSE: No, I'm glad you - literally, that

was my next question about the sister dynamic. The 
sibling dynamic was - between them, is so sharp.

Like, they will hit each other below the belt.
EVERETT: Yeah.

LUSE: On a regular basis. But then, will turn 
around and sometimes be the first person to

come to the other's rescue.
EVERETT: Right.

LUSE: And I think anybody with siblings 
could relate to their relationship. How

did you go about carefully building that dynamic?
EVERETT: What I really like and what we what we

all like, all of the writers and producers, is 
the way that those, you’re sort of on course

with two different kinds of relationships and how 
the friendship one can sometimes be a little more

gentle, at least in this instance. And then 
the familial one, the, the family one is, is,

is kind of just gloves off, you know what I mean? 
But, but they both are getting, they're both

moving Sam along. And, we didn't want Tricia to 
just be a b****. You know, she's a - first of all,

Mary Catherine, who plays Tricia, is an incredible 
actor, and you want to give her all the room in

the world to do as much as possible because she's 
so dynamic. And we lived - we were roommates for

eight years, so I've seen it all from her, you 
know, like - and she's seen mine. You know,

we have the dirt on each other. But um, I think 
that that kind of happens a lot. You see like, oh,

there's a sister. She's kind of one-note. She's a 
b****, and then maybe she redeems herself later,

but I think we all wanted Tricia to have lots, she 
has friends and a family, but, like, her life kind

of unravels. It's like everybody is doing the best 
they can, and things never really work out for any

of us the way that we, we hope to. And I think 
that, you know, Sam, being from a small town,

there's a lot of pressure to sort of do 
all the things that Tricia, her sister,

does do. But like by seeing the way that things 
aren't working out for Tricia, she's like, well,

I, I absolutely don't want that. You 
know, Holly, the sister that, you know,

we start the series off and she's been 
dead for, you know, six months or whatever,

and she was kind of the buffer, right? So Tricia 
and Sam are kind of learning to live with each

other without that. In my personal life, my sister 
who passed away was, like, you know, she was - she

believed in me. She loved me. She cared for me. 
In kind of, like, sort of a chaotic household,

she was gentle and maternal and loving. And that's 
how I think about Holly, who's passed away. But

I love that Sam and Tricia are finding a way, as 
painful as it is, to discover each other and to,

and to live with each other, because they, they 
have the common bond of family and they're not

giving up on each other, as much as I think 
Sam perfectly - if you would have started off

in season one, she would have been happy to 
never have a relationship with Tricia. But

um, I just love the slow road of them finding 
each other. I think it's really, really special.

LUSE: Something I love about Tricia that really 
makes her stand out on the show is her commitment

to the live, laugh love aesthetic.
EVERETT: Yeah.

LUSE: There's a plotline in season 
two that revolves around a pillow

of Tricia's that she sells, and, you know, 
she's selling online or selling, you know,

that says lying see you next Tuesday.
EVERETT: Yeah.

LUSE: Let's say. Let's say. Eventually, I 
mean, Tricia grows to have legion pillows with

sassy sayings on them. If you had to have one of 
Tricia's pillows in your home, what would it say?

EVERETT: Well, I do have some of those pillows, 
because I definitely - like, contributed some

of the names of the pillows that you will see in 
season two. And when we were wrapping that day,

I was like, oh, you don't mind if I take a 
couple of those - do you - for the house?

I, like - you know, there's a live, laugh...
LUSE: See you next Tuesday?

EVERETT: Yeah. Live, laugh - you know, 
I'll see you there. You know what I mean?

It makes me laugh. And it was so funny about it - 
you know, like, there's a line in the pilot where

Sam was like, there she is. Like, Sam knows 
that there is - like, Tricia’s always putting

on a front - right? - you know, when we first meet 
her. But, like, she's just like Sam underneath it.

But also, Sam was more like Tricia than she thinks 
she is, and the fact that they can come together

on these pillows is really delightful for me. And 
I think everybody should have one of those pillows

in their house. I mean, there used to be a time 
when I didn't say that word for a long, long time,

but now I feel like I like saying it. And for 
me, it's power. I'd like to be super... Super

C. You know, just something - actually, you know, 
I'm sick of going by Bridget Everett on stage. I'm

going to start going by Super C.
LUSE: (Laughter)

I - honestly, I feel like stock's going to 
go up. I feel like stock's going to go up if

you do that. I feel like it’s only positive.
EVERETT: Well also like, I don't like to use,

you know, like there's no reason to sort of throw 
out the word gratuitously. But like, Sam has a

foul mouth. Like, that's just how I've always 
talked. I used to always get in trouble for,

for kind of being too much and kind of, you know, 
I remember my swim coach sat me down and said, “Do

you ever think before the things come out of your 
mouth, come out of your mouth?” And I'm like, “No,

should I?” But I think that was also why I want to 
go to Kansas, because for a long time I felt like,

I'm, I don't fit in here. Like I don't play by 
the rules. I have, like a potty mouth and, and,

you know, farts make me laugh, and I know, 
but, um, yeah, I don't know. I think that

that's also kind of a big theme of the show 
is like Sam just trying to still realize it's

okay for herself to be a little naughty. So when 
Sam, so when Tricia, has one of those pillows,

it really makes her lean into Tricia a little. I 
think it's like a, a beautiful way to for sisters

to come together. Over the c***. Oh sorry, 
you can edit that out. Over the (mouths word).

(LAUGHTER)
LUSE: To move onto

another relationship on the show, the relationship 
between Sam and her BFF, Joel, it is so beautiful.

Their love is really the center of, I think, of 
the show. He's exactly the friend that everyone

wishes that they had. Right? And if you have a 
friend like that, then you cherish that person.

And it seems almost like to me, the whole show is 
framed around Joel's outlook on life, like, in the

sense that the show, I think, is really about 
people who want to be connected to one another.

EVERETT: Yes.
LUSE: Sam fights that to some degree.

Um, but Joel is so open and earnest. He's always 
looking for ways to, like, create community,

or, or go out on that date, or say hi to 
somebody. How does that tension drive the show?

EVERETT: I think that what he brings is, like, 
a warmth and a humor that kind of just allows

Sam to view life in a different way, which I 
think when you're in your 40s is really hard.

And when you're at this age, you need somebody 
who's going to sort of come at you from, you know,

nowhere and sort of knock you off your feet and 
lift you back slowly. And that's what he does.

LUSE: There's a moment that I think really speaks 
to Joel and Sam's relationship that happens

in season two. I will not get into explicit 
detail for those who have sensitive - you know,

sensitive spirits, but there is an extended poop 
joke between Sam and Joel in season two. And,

my editor has a theory that that poop 
jokes are most enjoyed by people under

ten and people over 40. Now, I'll say, I'm 35 
and I love a poop joke. Like they kill with me.

EVERETT: Yeah
LUSE: Like, I'm the crowd they kill with,

24/7. But what do you think about that? Like, 
I feel like that speaks to their intimacy,

right? The fact that, like, this kind of the...
EVERETT: That's exactly it.

LUSE: It's something you don't talk about.
EVERETT: Yeah. I think it's exactly - well,

we wanted to do something that would 
speak to their level of intimacy,

and this feels about as intimate as you could 
get. But um, I bought myself this golden

toilet as a wrap gift for season two.
LUSE: Really - it's darling. Wait,

does it open and close like that?
EVERETT: Yeah. It opens.

LUSE: Oh, that's cute.
EVERETT: Yeah. So I - I think

it's a reminder also to just, you know, not take 
life too seriously. And I realize that, you know,

maybe not everybody's going to - we might lose 
a few people on - because not everybody thinks

farts are funny, but I do. Guess what? I'm No. 
1 on the call sheet and the executive producer,

so it stays. And I'll tell you what, you know who 
never laughs harder is Carolyn Strauss and Carolyn

Strauss produced “Game of Thrones,” “The Last of 
Us,” and a host of other things. And if it makes

her laugh, then it's good for me.
(LAUGHTER)

LUSE: We see Sam throughout the show kind of 
use art and performance, and really, singing

as, like, an avenue for growth or, like, almost 
like for us as the viewer, like, a litmus

test of sort of where she is. One of the most 
heartbreaking moments of this season was when your

character, Sam, was doing a singing lesson and the 
teacher guides her through the warm ups, and Sam

becomes overcome by the feelings that it brings 
up, and she just leaves. It seems like the thing

that she loves most is almost, like, too painful 
for her to do. Like, singing, this thing - like,

there's all these moments throughout the show 
where we see Sam really expressing herself and

feeling free when she's singing, as long as she 
feels safe. But also, there's all these other

moments where singing almost feels impossible 
for her to do because she loves it so much.

EVERETT: Yeah.
LUSE: How do you relate your relationship to

singing to that moment or that feeling within Sam?
EVERETT: Well, I understand it. You know,

it's there because it's the way I feel 
about music and singing. It feels like,

it's like, when Sam sings especially 
something emotional that, you know, it,

it's kind of confronting her. You know, 
it's like, because it's undeniable. Like,

when, when Sam sings the song that she 
sings in the voice lessons - it's like,

I can't even talk about it because it's just also 
connected for me and for Sam. It's like it's,

it’s a love that's so deep and so personal. You 
know, it's just - it's the great love of her life.

It's - and I just can't talk about it.
LUSE:

It's interesting that you have such, like, a 
similar reaction to Sam about, about singing

- like, it strikes this emotional chord for you 
when it's, you know, the thing that perhaps,

you know, before this show, you were most known 
for. You have this huge personality on stage...

EVERETT: Yeah.
LUSE: ...Where you're, like,

belting out and playing with the audience. And 
it seems like it's also still this thing that's

very sacred for you, though, in a similar way.
EVERETT: Yeah, but, you know, in that way it's

a lot about, like, singing about different 
body parts and keeping it light and keeping

it fun. And - but I still - I sing ballads with 
my band and all that, but it's just, it's just,

I don’t know it’s the emotional throughline 
and - I guess I have a little work to do,

just like Sam does. Anyway.
LUSE: I think everybody has

something like that, though.
EVERETT: Yeah,

definitely. And mine’s just 
singing and so is Sam’s, you know?

I think there's something that the singing 
teacher says to Sam. You know, it's like,

it's almost too much to bear. And I think that 
that is - it's true. It's like, I feel like Sam

faces her pain when she sings because it's the way 
that she knows how to communicate. And she hasn't

been singing for so long. That's why. So.
LUSE: Hm.

EVERETT: So it’s heavy for her.
LUSE: It's like this - it's

like the channel through which she can 
kind of really, truly express herself.

EVERETT: Yeah.
LUSE: Maybe, perhaps one of the only

ones that she has and it makes it tender.
EVERETT: Yeah. Yeah (laughing).

Barbara Walters 2.0.
(LAUGHTER)

LUSE: I really don't intend for these things...
EVERETT: No, I mean, and I feel, like, silly,

like, how emotional it makes me. 
But it's just – it's just – it just,
it is. You know, it's, and I think it's kind of,

I think it's an interesting relationship 
that she has. And I'm glad that we sort of

you know, when we were talking about 
season two, I really wanted to have,

like, some more about the singing and 
about that relationship because it's what,

I think she just, it’s what gives her wings. 
You know, she hasn't had wings for a long time.

LUSE: Hm.
EVERETT:

I think what Sam is learning is, like, it doesn't 
have to be just one person that can kind of

give you life. You know, it can be singing - 
it can be a lot of things at the same time.

LUSE: Hm.
EVERETT: And, and, you know, I learned that when

I moved to New York and I met my showbiz family, 
my misfits. I want to, you know, like I discovered

that world. And I love the people I grew up with 
and I love the people I went to college with, but

the people that I know now understand me 
in a different way. And I think that that's

Sam's experience with Joel and the people 
around her and Fre Rococo and all that. So.

LUSE: Hm. Hm hm hm. That's 
such a really beautiful way

of putting it. Like, you can like, like, 
through Sam, but I think this is something

that applies to all of us. It's like 
you have to have multiple lifelines.

EVERETT: Yeah.
LUSE: Right?

EVERETT: Yeah.
LUSE: Otherwise, it's like, life becomes

almost impossible to get through.
EVERETT: Yeah.

LUSE: You’re so dependent on one…
EVERETT: And I think sometimes,

like in my own personal life, I'm like, well, 
I'll just give this person this much and I'll

give this person that much and I'll give, you 
know, so you're sort of like, spread out so

you're kind of safe, you know what I mean? But…
LUSE: Not, not, not, not divulging too much to any

one person. You're like, well, maybe I'll save…
EVERETT: Yeah.

LUSE: …my teenage trauma…
EVERETT: Yeah.

LUSE: …for this other friend.
EVERETT: Exactly. I'm like, what is that? Like,

you know, it's not like I’m trying to weaponize 
anything. It's just like I'm just trying to,

you know, and I think Sam does the same thing. 
She just wants to like, she wants to give

certain things to Joel, but not to Trisha. 
And. And I don't know. You can divvy it up

a little bit. Lighten up Sam (laughing).
LUSE: It sounds like what we’re kind of,

the thing that we’re talking 
around is just like being known,

EVERETT: Yeah.
LUSE: You know, whether it's being

seen in performance. Right. Being known by an 
audience, even if it's for just that context or…

EVERETT: Yeah.
LUSE: …in that slice of time,

but also being known in relationship.
EVERETT: Yeah.

LUSE: Being known in friendships and being 
known in family relationships, both intense.

EVERETT: Yeah. Yeah. In different ways.
LUSE: But yeah. No, I feel like allowing

yourself to be known.
EVERETT: Yeah.
